author: Jonathan Walker
title: 'We can't promise the North East will get its EU funding' admits the Government
text:
'We can't promise the North East will get its EU funding' admits the Government 05:30, 20 Jul 2016 By Jonathan Walker Government admits it can't currently guarantee the North East will get the cash allocated to it, but promises announcement soon Shares Get daily news by email Dominic Lipinski/PA Wire Treasury Minister David Gauke 
The Government has rejected pleas to re-think the North East devolution deal despite admitting that the region could lose hundreds of millions of pounds because of the decision to leave the European Union. 
MPs pointed out that the North East was due to receive almost £800 million. 
But Treasury Minister David Gauke admitted the Government could not currently guarantee the money would be provided, following the vote to leave the EU. 
Instead, he said Ministers would explain “in the not too distant future” what would happen to the cash. 
The new North East Combined Authority was due to take control of EU funding as part of a deal between local council leaders and the Government which included the creation of a directly-elected regional mayor, to be elected on May 4 2017. 
The goal is to let the North East authority “select projects for investment, to improve performance and maximise economic impact,” according to a written agreement with Ministers. South Shields MP Emma Lewell-Buck 
But the loss of EU funding would “push a coach and horses through that deal”, Bishop Auckland MP Helen Goodman warned. 
And South Shields MP Emma Lewell-Buck urged Ministers to draw up a new devolution deal - but her request was turned down. 
She told House of Commons: “Over the next five years alone, the North East was due to receive £726 million in EU funding, but the North East devolution deal promises only £30 million a year for 30 years.” 
The MP added: “With such high levels of uncertainty because of Brexit , is it not time he revisited all the devolution deals?” 
But Local Government Secretary Sajid Javid told her: “There is no need to reconsider any of the deals. These are good deals that have been reached by local leaders and central Government, and they will all, in turn, help to boost local growth.” 
Questioning Treasury Ministers, Mrs Goodman asked the Government if it could guarantee the money would be provided. 
She said: “Without a guarantee from the government, this will push a coach and horses through that deal.” PA Wire Helen Goodman 
David Gauke, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, said he could not make any guarantee now. 
He said: We recognise the need to bring any uncertainty to an end as soon as we possibly can 
“In the circumstances it is right that we take a moment before making any guarantees 
“But let me absolutely clear, as a government we remain committed to doing everything we can do to strengthen the Northern Powerhouse, to ensure that the north of England fulfils its full potential.” 
He added: “On the specific point, we will be making an announcement in the not too distant future.” 
There are a number of buildings and projects in the North East which benefitted directly from EU grants in the past. 
They include Portobello Trade Park in Durham, financed with £2.7m in European Regional Development Fund funding, Consett Business Park in Durham, which received £1.1m in ERDF funding, the regeneration of a 660-hectare area on the River Tyne North Bank, which benefitted from £2.4m in ERDF funding, and Core Science Central in Newcastle city centre, which was built with the support of £5.6m in ERDF funding.
